selected_quotes: Psychotherapy trials exclude lots of patients we need to treat. Does that mean they're not useful? #iopjc 1st May
Don't forget #iopjc TODAY, 11.30 Wolfson LT. Prof Trudie Chalder chairs, generalisability of psychotherapy trials
This week's #iopjc paper: Generalizability of psychotherapy trials in depression: influence of patient selection
The generalizability of psychotherapy efficacy trials in major depressive disorder: an analysis of the influence of …

citation.abstract: Treatment guidelines for major depressive disorder (MDD) are based on results from randomized clinical trials, among others in psychotherapy efficacy trials. However, patients in these trials differ from routine practice patients since trials use stringent criteria for patient selection. It is unknown whether the exclusion criteria used in psychotherapy efficacy trials (PETs) influence symptom outcome in clinical practice. We first explored which exclusion criteria are used in PETs. Second, we investigated the influence of commonly used exclusion criteria on symptom outcome in routine clinical practice.
citation.title: The generalizability of psychotherapy efficacy trials in major depressive disorder: an analysis of the influence of patient selection in efficacy trials on symptom outcome in daily practice
